results.headline: Review: In ‘In the Courtyard,’ a Neurotic Retiree Bonds With the Janitor
results.summary_short: Starring Catherine Deneuve, Pierre Salvadori’s film depicts an unlikely friendship between an anxious woman and a onetime musician who has hit bottom.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Courtyard

results.headline: Review: ‘In Country,’ Young Men Play at Fighting in Vietnam
results.summary_short: This documentary about Vietnam War re-enactors is sparse on explanations for why people might want to traipse through forests and fields playing war.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Country

results.headline: Review: ‘Dior and I,’ a Documentary That Peers Into a Storied Fashion House
results.summary_short: This documentary largely takes place in 2012, when Dior’s legacy is placed in the hands of Raf Simons, who has just eight weeks to produce his first couture collection for the company.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dior and I

results.headline: Review: ‘Desert Dancer’ Tells the Story of the Afshin Ghaffarian
results.summary_short: “Desert Dancer” is a fictionalized biopic about a dancer who left Iran in 2009 out of frustration with cultural repression.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Desert Dancer

results.headline: Review: ‘Broken Horses,’ Vidhu Vinod Chopra’s Modern Western
results.summary_short: Brotherly love and American cowboy-film conventions are interpreted here by an Indian director in an English-language film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Broken Horses

results.headline: Review: ‘Black Souls’ Depicts Crime Families Bound by Blood in Bad Ways
results.summary_short: A hotheaded 20-year-old reignites a long-dormant feud between Mafia clans in this drama from Francesco Munzi.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Souls

results.headline: Review: In ‘About Elly,’ a Middle Class Enjoying Itself Is Engulfed in Change
results.summary_short: Asghar Farhadi’s story of a young woman who disappears during a weekend outing at a coastal resort depicts the strains between Islamic traditions and modernism within Iran’s middle class.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Darbareye Elly

results.headline: Review: ‘Detective Byomkesh Bakshy!,’ a Calcutta Whodunit
results.summary_short: The detective, who first appeared in the 1930s in stories by Saradindu Bandyopadhyay, tackles a mystery in a film by Dibakar Banerjee.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Detective Byomkesh Bakshy

results.headline: Review: ‘The Forecaster’ Traces the Downfall of an Investment Manager
results.summary_short: This documentary about Martin A. Armstrong, accused of running a Ponzi scheme, intercuts the tale of his unraveling with his discussions of his financial models.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Forecaster

results.headline: Review: ‘That Guy Dick Miller’ Pays Tribute to a Character Actor
results.summary_short: Mr. Miller, whose film credits include “Gremlins” and Roger Corman’s “A Bucket of Blood,” is the subject of this jokey documentary directed by Elijah Drenner.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of That Guy Dick Miller

results.headline: Review: ‘Last Knights’ Has Sword Swinging and Cape Twirling in the Name of Revenge
results.summary_short: This medieval-esque potboiler has a simple code of devotion to one’s master, and mostly involves men, honor, vengeance, dramatic fights and the fantasy of the good death.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Knights

results.headline: Review: ‘Lambert & Stamp’ Recalls the Duo Who Helped Ignite the Who
results.summary_short: In a mix of archival footage and interviews, this nostalgic documentary portrays an unlikely music-world partnership.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lambert & Stamp

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Hand That Feeds,’ Workers Rise Up at a Hot & Crusty
results.summary_short: This documentary chronicles labor organizing by low-paid employees at a Manhattan bakery-cafe.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hand That Feeds

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Girl Is in Trouble,’ a Pretty Face Masks Danger
results.summary_short: A modern-day noir starring Columbus Short and Wilmer Valderrama focuses on how the tensions of immigration and gentrification have shaped the Lower East Side.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl Is In Trouble

results.headline: Review: In ‘Manos Sucias,’ Brothers Reconnect on a Drug Run
results.summary_short: In this Josef Kubota Wladyka film, two Colombian brothers with a cargo of cocaine reconnect during a trip along the Pacific Coast.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Manos Sucias

results.headline: Review: In ‘Boychoir,’ Dustin Hoffman Mentors a Troubled Student
results.summary_short: This well-acted drama directed by François Girard chooses a conclusion that is as neat and pretty as the music sung by the group of the title.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boychoir

results.headline: Review: ‘Effie Gray’ Stars Dakota Fanning as a Rejected Wife
results.summary_short: Written by Emma Thompson, this movie looks into the Victorian art critic John Ruskin’s famously unconsummated marriage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Effie Gray

results.headline: Review: ‘Cut Bank,’ Looking to Escape a Small Town and Its Eccentrics
results.summary_short: This comic neo-noir, directed by Matt Shakman, is filled with odd characters, facetious humor and a small sense of mystery.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cut Bank

results.headline: Review: ‘Cheatin’ ’ Conjures a Lusty Film-Noir Dreamscape
results.summary_short: The latest feature from the animator Bill Plympton is a pulpy, sex-addled opera rendered in fleet penciled lines and watercolor washes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cheatin'

results.headline: Review: ‘5 to 7,’ a New York Romance, With Nostalgia as Star
results.summary_short: Set in the indeterminate, immediate past, before smartphones became our greatest objects of desire, “5 to 7” takes place in a New York that looks, sounds and feels like a borrowed memory.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 5 to 7
